items.value: Guard your donuts.  Monster Match arrives May 2018.
In the town of Sprinkleton, monsters are running rampant and stealing all the donuts.  We need your help!

Monster Match is the screaming-fast game of catching cute, donut eating, monsters.  Players roll the special "Monster Dice" and then race to find a monster that matches the dice rolled.  How fast can you find a monster with 3 eyes…or 4 arms?  With each monster worth different donut points, do you search for just any matching monster, or do you try to find the monster with the most donuts?
But watch out! Go too fast, you might catch the wrong monsters and lose your donuts!
How to Play
Roll the dice.
Find the matching monsters.
The player with the most donut points wins!
Contents: 55 Monster Cards, 2 Monster Dice, 1 Zilch Token, 1 Rulebook, Monster Match Pouch, perfect for when on the run!

items.value: Question:  How should I store the bagels?
问：我该如何存放贝果？

Answer:  The bagels are individually vacuum packed for your convience and to extend the freshness of the bagels.  After recieving your bagel order you should immediately place them in the refrigerator or the freezer.  Your can store them up to 3 days in the refrigerator.  You can also freeze them from day one and they will be good in the freezer for at least 3 months. The freezer is the best way to store them for a short to long periods of time.
答：因为我们的产品是无任何添加的，在天气湿热的情况下，常温储存最多放置两天。所以收到我们的货品后尽快放入冰箱，冷藏可以储存3天，冷冻可以储存3个月。
Question: Are the bagels vegetarian, vegan, kosher?
问：贝果是素食产品，纯素食，清真的吗？
Answer: Our bagels are vegan (except our chocolate chip bagel) and vegetarian but is not kosher certified.
答：我们的贝果是纯素食的（除了巧克力贝果）但不是清真的。
Question: How do I prepare a bagel?
问：贝果有哪些吃法？
Answer:  First toast and add cream cheese, butter, or enjoy like many other breads
答：首先切，烤。根据个人喜好加芝士，黄油等。或者像其他面包类做法。

Answer: If you take the bagel out of the freezer you can let them slowly defrost in the refrigerator or on the shelf.  Cut in half and toast to a golden brown color or to your tasting.  NEVER MICROWAVE A BAGEL!  IT WILL COME OUT LIKE RUBBER.
答：如果你从冰箱拿出来的贝果，可以放常温慢慢解冻。然后切开两半，根据个人喜好烤成金黄色或者烤成你喜欢的程度。如果家里没有烤箱的，可以用平底锅煎（详情看下方，带图）。不可以用微波炉加热，否则口感会像橡皮筋一样，大打折扣。
Question:  Is there a minimum order?
问： 有最低订货量吗

Answer:  No, however, if you are just ordering bagels. we recommend you order at least 6.  6 bagels is 1kg and the shipping is the same price up to 1kg .so why not get as much product as possible for the same minimum shipping cost.
答：没有最低订货量，但是如果您只是要贝果的话建议您订六个，因为一到六个贝果的重量是1KG，首重不超过1KG的运费是一样的，所以买得越多越划算。

name: Graphic Novel Amulet 1-6
description: Graphic novel star Kazu Kibuishi creates a world of terrible, man-eating demons, a mechanical rabbit, a talking fox, a giant robot---and two ordinary children on a mission.

items.value: After the tragic death of their father, Emily and Navin move with their mother to the home of her deceased great-grandfather, but the strange house proves to be dangerous. Before long, a sinister creature lures the kids' mom through a door in the basement. Em and Navin, desperate not to lose her, follow her into an underground world inhabited by demons, robots, and talking animals.

Eventually, they enlist the help of a small mechanical rabbit named Miskit. Together with Miskit, they face the most terrifying monster of all, and Em finally has the chance to save someone she loves.

items.value: Pictionary Junior is a simplified version of the parent game, designed for a younger audience. Players divide into two teams, each with one Picturist and the rest of the players as Guessers. If there are only 3 players, one can act as full-time Picturist.

The game consists of rolling a die to circle a linear track on the board. Topics to draw come from cards. An hourglass marks the time limit for guessing. The cards contain simpler topics than the parent game, more suitable for children. Guessing correctly earns the next roll. The game is advertised for Ages 7 - 12.

name: Scrabble Apple - Bananagrams - Pairs in Pears
description:
More than a game, this is also one of my favorite teaching tools because it can be used in many different ways by many different ages and levels of students. 

A fun way for children to develop memory and cognitive skills while learning alphabetical order, word construction, vowels, vocabulary, rhyming, and more.

Read more below for some ideas and how to play, or ask in our wechat groups for more help!

items.value: How to Play:

Banagrams uses letter tiles to create a grid of words, but in this game no structure is permanent. Players start with a set number of letters and use them to create their own word grid. When one player has used all of his letters, everyone must draw another tile and incorporate it into their own structures. Each person can rearrange his word grid as desired. This game can be fast paced when higher-level students play, but even with less advanced students it is a ready source for learning new vocabulary. In addition, it teaches students flexibility with words and spelling structures.

Scrabble Apple: Flip over the tiles, one at a time. The first to make a new word, or build off an oponent's word, gets the word and the points. (Red tile double your word score.) Think fast, or your words will get swiped before you can say, "Scrabble Apple" To win, have the most points when the tiles are gone. It's a very a-peel-ing way to polish up your word-forming skills!
The
Pairs in Pears

game involves making pairs of intersecting words that consist of tiles of all the same pattern. One word is up/down and the other is left/right, and they share a vowel or consonant. Whoever makes a certain number of word pairs first, wins.
Pairpoints
is a variation that includes a more elaborate scoring scheme (1 point for non-pattern-matching words, 2 points for matching words, 5 points for finishing first).

The tiles show capital letters in four designs: solid, outline, lines and dots. The different patterns function like different suits of cards. As there are four suits, each containing a complete alphabet, there are a total of 104 tiles. Just as in a deck of cards, each tile is unique (e.g., the G of solids or the H of dots). This adds an interesting new dimension to play with (although the games in the rules only ask that a word consist of same-pattern letters).

The instructions emphasize the educational value of the tile set: a fun way for children to develop memory and cognitive skills while learning alphabetical order, word construction, vowels, vocabulary, rhyming, and more.
How to adapt:

For younger students, put these letter tiles into a plastic container with rice/beans/corns and create a sensory experience while searching for the letters. Students up to 8 years old will enjoy this activity, but you must make the game increase in difficulty. For example:
Find the letter A.
Find the letter that makes the sound /b/
Find the first letter of "cat"
Find the letters in your name.
Find the vowels.

For older students, remember that even if they are older they still might not be able to spell many words so the game might not be fun if they're not ready. Use spelling or vocabulary lists in their notebooks or on the whiteboard to help them while playing. You could also put the tiles in a bag and use them for other games like:
Pull out ten letters, try to make a word with those letters. How many different words can you make?
Pull out 5 letters, try to make a sentence or phrase. "F R E T P" "Four really excited turtles play."
To practice writing, have them do these same type of activities but write down answers instead.
Use these for arts and crafts.
For large classes, buy multiple sets and have competitions.

A year has passed since the start of the Clone Wars on Geonosis. The Galactic Republic has since become engulfed with all-out warfare against the Confederacy of Independent Systems. The effects of this galaxy-wide struggle have been felt in every facet of the Republic. Take command of the Republic "Clone Trooper" Army or lead the Separatists in their universal conquest to topple the Old Republic as a players wage war on numerous planetary battlegrounds in the galaxy's most unforgettable conflict in the exciting Riskvariant.
Components:
4 armies each containing:
15 tanks
35 transformers
Quelf is the unpredictable party game that gives Random a new name!
Whether you're answering hilarious trivia, performing ridiculous stunts, or obeying silly rules, Quelf will inspire you to use your creativity, wit and sense of humor in ways you've never imagined.

As you move around the game board, as one of eight quirky characters, crazy things start to happen. Your friends start talking strangely. Your mom's face is wrapped in toilet paper. Your dad is acting like Dracula. And you are reciting a poem about your armpits.
Cards:
Stuntz - balancing acts, costume creations, daredevil moves, weird contraptions
Showbiz - mime, sing, tapdance, draw, do impressions, write poetry
Quizzle - mind-twisting trivia, nutty riddles, brain teasers
Rulez - rules you must follow: snort like a pig when you laugh, say everything twice, roll the dice with your elbows
Scatterbrainz - choose one of two topics and everyone gives answers until no one can think of a valid one ("Ways to get your leg out of a spring-loaded, steel bear trap" or "Brands of Lipstick")
Characters:
The Platypus
Mr. Lugnut
Super Ninja Monkey
The Dude
The Biscuit Farmer
Queen Spatula
Batbileg Chinzorig
Mrs. Pickle Feather

Taboo is a party word game. Players take turns describing a word or phrase on a drawn card to their partner without using five common additional words or phrases also on the card. The opposing partners watch a timer and use a buzzer to stop the game, buzz the player describing if one of the five off limits words or phrases is used, or the describing player makes any gestures. The describing team gets a point for each card they guess successfully and the opposing team gets a point for each card they pass on, make gestures on, or lose for saying one of the off limits words or phrases. An excellent party game!

A player draws a card with a list of charades, then rolls a die to see which one to act out. There is also a deck of picture cards for players too young to read. The active player acts out the charade for the player on the left. This player gets only one chance to guess. If incorrect, the next player gets one chance, and so on. The first player to guess correctly moves two spaces along the game board. The player doing the charade moves ahead one space. If no one guess correctly, then no one moves for that turn. There are also "All Play" spaces where everyone guesses simultaneously. The first player to reach the finish space wins.

In Kingdomino, you are a Lord seeking new lands in which to expand your kingdom. You must explore all the lands, wheat fields, lakes, and mountains in order to spot the best plots. But be careful as some other Lords also covet these lands...

Dominoes with a kingdom building twist. Each turn, connect a new domino to your existing kingdom, making sure at least one of its sides connects to a matching terrain type already in play. The game mechanics for obtaining the tiles is clever: the order of who picks first depends on which tile was previously chosen. Make sure to secure tiles with crowns- these royal treasures help to multiply the worth of your kingdom at the end of the game! The game ends when each player has completed a 5x5 grid, and then points are counted based on number of connecting tiles and crowns.

AWARDS & HONORS2017 Spiel des Jahres Winner2017 Spiel des Jahres Nominee2017 Gouden Ludo Best Family Game Winner2017 Gouden Ludo Best Family Game Nominee2017 As d'Or - Jeu de l'Année Nominee2016 Tric Trac Nominee2016 Golden Geek Best Family Board Game Nominee

7 Ate 9 is a quick-playing card game in everyone wants to rid themselves of cards as quickly as possible — but you can't play just any card you want! Each card features a large numeral (1-10) as well as a smaller numeral in the corner (±1, ±2, or ±3).

To play, place one card face down in the center of the table, deal the remaining cards out evenly among all the players, then reveal the central card. Players race to add the next card to the central pile. A card with a large 5 and a ±2 in its corner, for example, could be covered by either a 3 or a 7 (since 5-2=3 and 5+2=7). The first player to get rid of all their cards wins.

description: Video come soon!

items.value: In Alles Tomate!, players are farmers who keep forgetting where they put their belongings. To set up the game, seven topic cards with different colored backgrounds are laid out. The yard card deck consists of 49 cards – seven each with one of the seven background colors, with each card showing a different image. One card of each background color is laid out below the appropriate topic card, which depicts the seven images in that color. Each player tries to memorize the cards, which are then turned face down.

On a turn, one player reveals a yard card and the first player to name the yard card of the same color currently face-down in the display claims that card, with the newly revealed card put in its place. If two players name the card at the same time, each player claims a card with extra drawn off the deck as needed; if no one names the card, the face-down card is placed back in the deck while the new card is put in its place. When the yard deck runs out, the player with the most cards wins.

name: Plush Balls - ABC
description:
Perfect for a variety of classroom games (even for adults)
Machine washable. 

For other colors, please contact customer service for availability.

For large orders, we offer a discount. 
发票 "fapiao"s are also available digitally.

items.value: Spelling Ball

This game is as simple as ABC. Have your students stand in a big circle. Say a word and toss the ball to one of your students. Student says the first letter of the word and tosses the ball to a classmate, who has to say the second letter, and then tosses the ball to another. Students who make a mistake must sit down and play starts again with the teacher. The last student standing is the winner! OR just have the students start over if they make a mistake. Have them race against a clock if you need the added excitiment of "competition"
Shoot for Points

Set up a trash can, bin, or any container that will serve as your “basket”. Students line up. Choose a topic or grammar point, for example past simple. Ask each student a question: Where did you go last weekend? If student uses the verb in simple past correctly, they may shoot for points: 10 points if they score; 5 if they miss, but answered the question correctly.
Freeze!

This game is ideal for little ones! Practice vocabulary with flashcards. First, teach students the meaning of “Freeze!” as stop. OR just use "Stop!" Students sit in a wide circle with flashcards in the center. Students pass the ball around the circle. Tell them they can’t hold the ball for more than a second. Cover your eyes while they do this and say, “Freeze!” The student who has the ball must stop and take a flashcard from the pile. Depending on your students’ ages and level, ask them to either say the word or use it in a sentence.
It’s a bomb!

This is a great way for students to introduce themselves and learn their classmates’ names. Also a fun way to practice or review possessive pronouns. Have students sit in a circle. Give one of them the ball, and say, “It’s a bomb! The timer is ticking (use a timer!) Tell them they have to say their name, pass the ball, and say their classmate’s name: My name is John. Your name is Lily. The student who has the “bomb” when the timer goes off, leaves the circle OR answers a question. Have students re-arrange themselves in the circle so they’re sitting next to different students, and start again.
Description Dodgeball
Use a very light, soft ball for this game, as students will be trying to hit each other!

Have students line up on one side of the classroom (if you can play this in the schoolyard, better!) One student stands in the front next to you holding the ball. Describe one of the students in your class: This student is the tallest in the class. The student you are describing has to run to avoid being hit by the student with the ball. If the student is hit, he/she becomes the next thrower. You may also have students wear tags with names of cities, animals, or places for you to describe.
Basketball Dare - Practice Giving Commands

Set up a “basket” far enough away for it to be a challenge, but not impossible for students to score. Students line up and shoot for the basket. If students score, they get to give the teacher a command you must follow: “Walk like a monkey”, “Say something in a baby voice”, “Stand on one foot for 30 seconds”, etc… Make sure you establish some ground rules, for example, students can’t give you commands that involve shouting, leaving the classroom, etc…

They are sold at very low prices not because they are fake, but because they were not suitable for export (a creased spine, test print run, over stock, etc) We go to the warehouse and HAND-PICK the best quality and titles for our customers! If any small defect makes the book unusable, please return it to us for store credit.

name: Chinese New Year Books
description: Here are a few books about Chinese New Year your students might enjoy. Please check for availability before purchase for all holiday items.

items.value: Chinese New Year Dragon

Gr. 3-5. A little girl tells the story of her family's Chinese New Year celebration. Although the cover illustration shows the girl riding a dragon and the first page promises magic, the majority of this book deals with the holiday as a family event --from cleaning and shopping to food preparation and gifts. Street parades and fireworks are only incidental; this story takes place in a middle-class kitchen, living room, and dining room. The girl cleans the house in her jeans, but she wears traditional clothing (with red sneakers) for the family party. The magical happening is a tiny, dreamy moment when the girl feels she's back in ancient China, watching the celebration from a dragon's back. The pictures show a world in which tradition intersects a nontraditional world: the New Year's fireworks explode against an urban skyscape.

2 players

items.value: You’ve entrusted your nine courtiers to deliver a beautiful love letter to Princess Persephone, but your opponent also has nine courtiers delivering an equally moving love letter to the same princess! In each case 8 letters are decoys and only the letter with the red seal is the “true love letter”. Intercept your rival’s true love letter to make sure that only your letter sways her affections. Each of the 3 types of character pieces carries a letter, has a mirror on the back of the piece, and has a special way of moving on the board similar to chess. When your piece lands on an opponent’s piece, you must say what color seal is on their letter. If correct, that piece is removed from play. Otherwise your piece is removed from play, so choose carefully and make liberal use of your mirrors to discover the color of the seals on your opponent’s pieces before venturing to intercept their letters!
Game Components:
Game board
18 Plastic holders with mirrors (9 gold and 9 blue)
18 Characters tiles

name: Happy Salmon 【Games Warehouse】
description:
Ages: 6+   |   Players: 3-6   |  
The High-Fivin', Fin-Flappin' Card Game

Great active game, super fun and a great brain break in between classes or after long study sessions with older students.

items.value: Description from the publisher:
Happy Salmon is a simple, ultra-fast, very silly card game.

There are no turns. Players call out the action shown on their cards as fast as they can. When two players have a match, they celebrate by performing the action. Actions include the classic "High 5", the unifying "Pound It", the frantic "Switcheroo", and the delightful and bizarre "Happy Salmon".
Each time a player celebrates a match, they quickly discard a card. The first person to get rid of all their cards wins.
The "FIN-tastically" unique and cute fish pouch makes
Happy Salmon
perfect to take to camp, vacation or if you are just traveling upstream.

Happy Salmon is the simple, fast-paced card game packed to the gills with high-fivin’, fin-flappin’ fun. Actions including the classic "High 5", the unifying "Pound It", the frantic "Switcheroo", and the delightful “Happy Salmon” will leave players doubled over in laughter. With so many mini-celebrations built into the play, it’s the happiest game ever!

items.value: The Macroscope is a wonderous device that's used to investigate things up close... provided you can figure out what it is you're looking at. Roll the dice to determine which windows of the Macroscope you can open, revealing more of the picture inside.
The fewer windows you open before guessing, the greater the reward if you're right, or penalty if you're wrong.
After 10 images, the player with the highest score is the winner!  There are 400 images in the game so there is a TON of replayabilty in the game.

description:
WAS 272 RMB, now only 260!

items.value: The game comes with four identical sets of ten paintings, each depicting a scene packed (to greater and lesser extents) with various objects. Each of up to four players or teams uses their own set, so there’s no craning around to see the picture at the far end of the table. In fact, spiffy cardboard easels prop up the scenes nicely so they’re easier to view. Everyone loads identical scenes onto their easels and a deck of cards provides a letter for the round. Everyone gets sixty seconds to write down as many things beginning with that letter as they can find in the scene. Although each word can be used only once - a football and baseball wouldn’t count as two BALLS - an object can be used multiple times for different words (e.g., BASEBALL, BALL). Once time has expired, players read through the lists. Any object on multiple lists scores one point for those who wrote it. Any item unique to a single list scores three points. When all lists have been scored everyone advances to the next scene and a new letter is chosen. The high score after all 12 scenes wins.

items.value: This game consists of three dice and a set of poker chips. Each player starts with three chips and on their turn a player rolls the three dice. For each "L" rolled, they give a chip to the player on their left. For each "R" rolled, they give a chip to the player on their right. For each "C" rolled they put a chip in the middle of the table. For each dot rolled, nothing occurs. The dice are then passed to the next (clockwise) player. If at any point, only one player has all of the chips, that player wins the game.

For class?

I think games are exciting and a great way for students to practice speaking with FEELING! Help your students to stop sounding like robots and get some emotion in their voices! 

Join our network for more great ideas

name: Mr. Jack (New York & London)
description:
One of my favorite two player games! When you get tired of playing Chess and Checkers, try this interesting game. 

Best for:
Older students, private classes. The theme is a little dark so I tend to say it's the "bad guy" and the "police man" game. 

Each player controls a range of characters and moves them around the board. The police man is trying to discover which character is the killer and the killer is trying to escape the board. 

We will email English instructions (and other interesting related files) when you purchase this!

items.value: Description from www.boardgamegeek.com:

In Mr. Jack, one of the two players represents Jack the Ripper, who will be one of the eight characters on the board. This player knows which character is Mr. Jack, and his goal is to flee from the district as soon as possible (or avoid being accused for eight turns). The other player represents an independent investigator (not represented on the board) who tries to guess the identity of Jack — but he can make only one accusation during the game!

During each turn, the players move the characters, using their special powers and placing them either in shadow or light. At the end of each turn, the witnesses declare whether Jack is visible — that is, in light or adjacent to another character — or not (alone in the shadows). This allows the investigator to know which characters are innocent. As the turns progress, the investigator tries to eliminate suspects while Jack tries to escape. Intuition, logic, and cold blood will be necessary for each of the two participants.
This version includes Mr. Jack, and Mr. Jack in New York:

Stand alone variant of Mr. Jack. As in Mr. Jack, one player takes the role of Mr. Jack, the other takes a role of a Detective. But there are new possibilities - gaslights and manholes are represented by pawns which can be moved.The game takes place in Manhattan, and surrounding water is very important for escape of Mr. Jack. Characters will have new powers and there will be also a police spy, who will be able to get valuable information. This version of the game is more strategic and complex so it is suitable for more advanced players.

name: Battle Ship - The Sea Battle
description:
Classic 2 player game where you try to find your opponents ships and destroy them! 

For class use?
Try this with 1-1 students for practicing numbers and letters. Instead of calling the ships by name (Battleship, Tanker, Destroyer) You could make a list with different target words and re-name the ship. 

Put this game in your classroom to be used during free time or a reward for students that finish first. 

Make sure they get all the pieces back in the box! Practicing counting by having them count to make sure all the pieces are there!

name: Snack Attack
description:
Ages 4+ and up to 6 players (Teacher Tip: Have them in teams of two!)

Skills Learned:
Matching
Visual Recognition (Use for identifying letters and words)
Memory and Concentration
Observation and Perception
Fine Motor Skills and Coordination
Following Instructions
Taking Turns
Winning and Losing
Expanding Vocabulary and Sentences

items.value: Description from www.BoardGameGeek.com:

In this fast-paced, picture matching, token-stacking game, players race to identify and collect the most food items to place on their snack plates. During the game, one player acts as the "chef" and rotates the spinner around the platter dispensing seven food items. All players then compete to call out items matching those on their individual snack plates, flipping the tokens that are won to reveal new snacks to match. At the end of the game, the player with the most snacks on their plate wins!
Why I like this game...
It gives us a chance to talk about healthy snacks and unhealthy snacks.
We read "Hungry Little Caterpillar" to go along with this game.
It's great for mixed ages and English levels, so perfect for those winter/summer camps and other surprise classes!
PRO TIP: In order to make this game last a long time, and to practice counting, be sure to make sure all the pieces get back in the box! Count them all!
I also wrote a short song, join our group for Preschool - Grade 3 Teachers and I will sing it for you!
Includes Instructions in Chinese and English
Parent's Guide contains more ideas for game play!
Other ways to use this game:
You can use the pieces as points tokens for any age class.
You can hide the pieces and have students search for them shouting "I found the ____"
You could use them for a quick art lesson, let the students make their own plates of snacks they like!

name: Blurble  【Games Warehouse】
description:
A great game for Intermediate students OR a wonderful set of small flashcards for increasing vocabulary or telling stories.

This game is a wonderful addition to any classroom because it's adaptable. 

Read below to see how to play.

items.value: Here's how you play:

One person starts as the 'Blurbler' (the deck-holder). The Blurbler flips a card face-up between the person to the left and him/herself.  The race is on between these two opponents!  The first to say an English word (or choose another language) that starts with the same letter as the image on the card wins.  I know this may sound easy, but there's a catch.  Proper nouns, numbers, and words with fewer than 3 letters cannot be used.  Here's an example:

The card is flipped and you see the image above...You yell, "Knife" - but that starts with 'K', not 'N'.  "Nicole" - nope, proper noun.  "No" - not enough letters.  "Nine" - sorry, no numbers allowed.  By the time you've finally uttered a word that counts, your opponent has already shouted "Ninja," the whole table has had a good laugh, and you've been defeated.
Great for Kids:

Blurble is a great game for young children!  Unlike many games that are simply too difficult for a child to grasp, Blurble can be picked up very quickly and kids love the cute characters!  As soon as children are able to identify common pictures and have picked up the fundamentals of spelling, they are ready for the basics of Blurble.  Check out my 'For Kids!' page on my website by clicking HERE to see lots of great ways to use Blurble as a fun educational tool for children of all ages.
The birth of Blurble: From the Creator

I invented this game years ago, simply to play with my friends, but the overwhelming positive feedback encouraged me to take it to the next level.  What started out as a 100 card deck of self-laminated Google images pasted to note cards has transformed into a professionally illustrated, high quality printed deck of 300 cards.  The art alone is a pleasure to look at...not that you'll have much time to admire it when your turn is up.  Over the years, the game has been played among several groups of my friends for hundreds of hours, and has been a hoot every time!  I know you'll love Blurble as much as we do!

When I set out to bring Blurble to a larger audience, I knew how important it would be to find an artist who's work would define the game and appeal to all audiences. I wanted a style that was bright and crisp, unique and friendly, cute but not too cute. After exploring several art forums and searching through numerous artists' profiles, I found exactly what I was looking for. Her name is Erin Koehler and she is the mastermind of design behind every Blurble image. Erin is a freelance artist, currently living in Portland, Oregon. She is an illustrator and art director for books, apps, films, and most recently, games!

name: Paperback - A Novel Deckbuilding Game【Games Warehouse】

You are a paperback author trying to finish novels for your editor. Complete Westerns, Science Fiction, Romance or even the rare Best-Seller. Live the dream — and maybe pay the bills.

Word-building meets deck-building in the unique game Paperback. Players start with a deck of letter cards and wild cards. Each hand they form words, and purchase more powerful letters based on how well their word scored. Most letters have abilities that activate when they are used in a word, such as drawing more cards or double letter score. Players buy wilds to gain victory points.

name: Jigsaw Puzzle
description:
You can buy them separately or as a full set. 
Use these in many different ways:

For large groups, buy a full set, give a group of 4 students a puzzle and let them work together. Change puzzles every 15 minutes. 

For review work: Let students answer review questions, let them pull a puzzle piece from a bag, which team has the most matches is the winning team. 

Scroll down for more ideas:

items.value: Hide and Seek - Hide the pieces around the room then let the students ask questions about where they might be. (Extra bonus! Practicing prepositions and room objects!) Then let them go and look. When they find it have them shout out what they found!

Use these with older learners (but low level) for finding partners for another activity. Shuffle the pieces and hand them out randomly to each student, then have them look to find the match, that's the new partner.
Give half of the puzzle to the students, the other half put in a bag and have one student choose it, and act it out. The student who has the matching piece can go next!
They are self-correcting (That means they can't connect unless they match!) So they are great to use in "corners" or self guided activity times or before or after class when waiting for parents.
Buy two sets of the same and have students or teams race against each other to complete the whole set.

Loud and Active activity: Give each student three cards (that don't match) then they have to walk around the room shouting out what they have, when they find their partner, they bring it to the teacher and both say the word.

name: Bang!
description:
How can we use this for class? It's a great game where they have to discuss with people what actions they should take while bluffing or hiding their role in the game. If you pre-teach the vocabulary and some phrases there will be plenty for them to say!

You could write words on the board or have them write and translate in their notebooks. Or you could prepare a small "cheat sheet" for them. Sometimes it's good practice to let the students create these materials themselves.

Best for grade 5 and up... and even with adults! I still enjoy playing this game with my friends as well.

items.value: From BoardGameGeek.com

"The Outlaws hunt the Sheriff. The Sheriff hunts the Outlaws. The Renegade plots secretly, ready to take one side or the other. Bullets fly. Who among the gunmen is a Deputy, ready to sacrifice himself for the Sheriff? And who is a merciless Outlaw, willing to kill him? If you want to find out, just draw (your cards)!"
(From back of box)
The card game
BANG!
recreates an old-fashioned spaghetti western shoot-out, with each player randomly receiving a Character card to determine special abilities, and a secret Role card to determine their goal.
Four different Roles are available, each with a unique victory condition:
Sheriff - Kill all Outlaws and the Renegade
Deputy - Protect the Sheriff and kill any Outlaws
Outlaw - Kill the Sheriff
Renegade - Be the last person standing
A player's Role is kept secret, except for the Sheriff. Character cards are placed face up on table, and also track strength (hand limit) in addition to special ability.

There are 22 different types of cards in the draw deck. Most common are the BANG! cards, which let you shoot at another player, assuming the target is within "range" of your current gun. The target player can play a "MISSED!" card to dodge the shot. Other cards can provide temporary boosts while in play (for example, different guns to improve your firing range) and special one-time effects to help you or hinder your opponents (such as Beer to restore health, or Barrels to hide behind during a shootout). A horse is useful for keeping your distance from unruly neighbors, while the Winchester can hit a target at range 5. The Gatling is a deadly exception where range doesn't matter: it can only be used once, but targets all other players at the table!
Information on the cards is displayed using language-independent symbols, and 7 summary/reference cards are included.

Description from Oncers.com: (A Website for Online Teachers!)
Finger puppets are PERFECT for online teaching because you can move them close to the webcam and make them seem much bigger. They are also easy to pack and store and have great visual impact. Watch your students face light up when one of these little puppets walk onto the screen space!

items.value: Online Teachers please check out Onchers.com and please join their online support group here to learn more about puppetry and other general online teaching tips!
Suggestions:
Not a ventriloquist? It doesn't matter! The student will be captivated by the puppet when it's onscreen and will enjoy speaking to a new character.
We usually move the puppet in front of our mouth when it's speaking. This is an easy way to hide your mouth moving!
Use puppets to reinforce new language, to reward the student or to just add some energy to the class if the student starts to lose focus.
Give your puppet a name and character and keep this name and character the same in each class.
Have the puppet 'visit' for a chat at the end of class to review the class content: "Hi! What did you learn today? Can you tell me?"

name: Hip Hip Hooray Textbooks
Super Tots
description:
Paperback
Publisher: Pearson Education Asia (August 2, 2001)
Language: English
ISBN-10: 0130212326
ISBN-13: 978-0130212320
Product Dimensions: 8.7 x 1.2 x 10.7 inches
Shipping Weight: 3.5 pounds

items.value:
SuperTots provides a solid base for even the youngest of students to develop their language skills.

This series contains an engaging mix of fun activities, lively songs, chants, games, TPR and optional crafts to keep students motivated.

 

  • Simple easy-to-teach dialogs promote pair and group speaking
  • Child-centered themes and vocabulary
  • Phonics practice introduced through familiar vocabulary
  • 8 pages of pull-out stickers for personalization and reward
  • Split Editions - combination of Student Book and Activity Book into one text - are ideal for those little hands
  • Activity Books provide follow up and support and feature a wide variety of activities for use in class or at home
  • Teacher's Books, available in English and Japanese, contain approximately eighty games in an Activity Bank, musical scores for all the songs with actions described too, and a full set of photocopiable picture cards

name: Everybody Up!
description:
This amazing set of books is perfect for primary students. It includes workbooks, PDFs, and audio files. 

Contact us for digital files after purchase.

items.value: Everybody Up gets students talking about the real world. Posters, videos, stories, and songs link English to other school subjects and universal values, developing global citizens with 21st century skills.
NEW Posters and documentary-style videos
– We’ve enhanced the cross-curricular lessons with new videos to bring the outside world into the classroom, and colorful posters to spark off group discussion.
NEW Projects
– Fancy making a robot, designing a restaurant menu, or working on a group story project? These creative, hands-on activities get students working together to activate new language.
NEW Grammar animations
–These allow you to present language patterns in a more memorable way.
NEW 21st Century skills focus

– The Everybody Up friends appear in each of the core lessons, providing activities to develop critical thinking, communication, collaboration, and creativity. Every lesson includes pair and group speaking tasks, giving children plenty of opportunities to work together.
Fun stories teach universal values
– Be kind. Be helpful. Be safe. Values like these are woven into the reading lessons, giving children the functional language they need to communicate as responsible global citizens.
NEW Online Play
– These language games encourage students to practice at home. Children unlock new levels as they progress, motivating them to keep playing.
NEW Assessment for learning package

–Monitor your students’ progress with the new Check Up pages which review the material covered every 2 units. Each Student Book also includes 8 new pages of Cambridge English: Young Learners practice activities to prepare children for exams. The Teacher’s Resource Center CD-ROM provides a full suite of tests, giving you plenty of material to use throughout the year.

name: Go Native (Includes CDs)
description: This set of books has 2 levels. Great to use for private lessons.

name: American School Textbook Listening & Speaking Key
Super Kids
description: Each level includes 1 student's book and 1 workbook.

name: Let's Go Set (Text, Workbook, Test booklet + CD)
description:
Let's Go is the world's best-selling coursebook for a reason - a quality syllabus that covers conversation, listening, phonics and reading in a way that will have kids communicating from the first lesson!
Packed full of songs, chants and activities that work, Let's Go will help the teacher make the classroom a place of excitement and real communication.

name: Oxford Phonics World
description: Each level includes 1 student's book with 2 interactive Multi-ROMs, and 1 Workbook

items.value:
A comprehensive international phonics series to get young learners reading, Oxford Phonics World is the first step on your students' journey into English, leading you through all 44 sounds.

 

 

This brand new 5-level phonics course can be used before or alongside a main course book. Thought-provoking and engaging activities let children actively apply what they learn. They learn to really read, not just memorize words and sounds.

  • Comprehensive syllabus that covers 44 sounds in English.
  • Thought-provoking activities teach children to read, not just memorize words.
  • Songs, chants and games encourage children to discover connections between English sounds and letters.
  • Multi-ROM full of fun interactive activities allows learning to continue outside the classroom.
  • Great to use as a phonics course before coursebooks such as Let's Go or Everybody Up, or at the same time as extra support.

name: Junior New Concept English

name: Sleeping Queens
description:
This beautiful game is one of my student's favorite. 

At first I thought it would be too difficult for the 5 year old students to learn, but once they played through one or two times everyone did really well. This game teaches some basic addition skills and there are plenty of vocabulary words that can be used when talking about which cards you are playing.

Scroll down for more info and a vocabulary list.

items.value:
Ages 5+

2-5 Players

 

Good for:

   Before/After class or short breaks

   Additional Skills

You need a table big enough to put cards in front of players. 

 

Teachers: Here is a list of all the words that you could use during this game. 

 

 Vocabulary:

Additional Rules for ESL Class: If you speak Chinese, the teacher will make one of your Queens go to sleep OR take a card from your hand and return to the bottom of the deck.

name: Scrabble
description: Scroll down for product description.

items.value:
Suitable for ages 4 and up! 
 
Scrabble seems like the perfect game for English classes, right? WRONG this game is extremely hard when you have a low vocabulary and no strong base of phonics to sound out words. So instead of having fun challenge opponents to a battle of wits, this becomes a tedious game of checking dictionaries and being disappointed.
 
BUT this JUNIOR version, it’s perfect! It’s two-in-one, so you save money AND you can use it for different levels of students.
 
Before playing this board game I recommend playing “hangman” on the whiteboard or a game called, “Egg Game” or even some simple crossword puzzle print outs. Join our VIP group for more information and files.
 
If you’re just wanting to get a set of the letter tiles, please look for Banangrams! It’s like scrabble without the board! Check that listing for more ideas on how to use just the tiles in many exciting ways!
 
Recommended for 4 players, or groups of 2.
Also works for 1-1 classes. But you might want to give yourself some “handicap” in the game to make it more fair.

name: Original Twister
description: Scroll down for more class ideas and more details.

items.value:
Twister -
Ages 3 and up!
 
What’s not to love about Twister? Learn a few colors, and body parts, great for basics. BUT...
 
For young learners - Don’t compete against each other, but instead, race the clock! 

 

Want to practice reading? Use word cards instead of calling out. Want to practice speaking, let an advanced student be the “caller” See if they can follow a pattern you make up. Use it like a DDR board. Another class idea is to write or tape word cards and let them practice touching, hitting, sitting, smashing or tossing bean bags. 

You can also hang it on the wall or whiteboard. 

 

**Don’t forget to tape down the corners for safety!**

No more than 4 people at once. 

 

Got a holiday or party coming? Buy multiple copies and tape them together for ULTIMATE twister with parents and students! 

 

 

So many things you can do with this! I can’t imagine a classroom without this amazing game.
 
For small children, no need to compete, just let them roll around touching the colors with different body parts. As they grow older, let them learn more.
 
For upper primary up through adults, this game is a little difficult because some Chinese learners are a bit shy. You can try it as an icebreaker, but I recommend separating girls and boys and making sure no one is wearing a skirt!
 
Practicing topics more advanced than colors? Let each color represent an error, for example “Red = Wrong subject+verb agreement, Green = No problems, Blue = wrong word choice, Yellow = wrong tense” then read sentences from the textbook making mistakes on purpose!
 
Three versions available:
Original Twister
Twister MOVES - spinner board has additional movements on it.

Not enough classroom space? Can't move tables and chairs? Try FINGER Twister!

name: Zingo!
description:
Just like playing a classic game of Bingo, except:
2 levels of play
6 double-sided zingo cards and 72 double-sided tiles
Easy to clean up

Different versions teach different skills: Counting, simple addition, number sense and sight word recognition

Scroll down for more info.

items.value:
How to play:

Teacher will call out the words.Players raise their hands or shout out to win the tiles. Then match the tiles to images on their cards. The first player with a full card wins by yelling "Zingo." 

 

For shorter games, just have them get one "line" of pictures covered. 

For younger players, play until everyone wins. Let the student that wins first help others.

 

Game is sturdy, pieces are well made.

We recommend at least 3 people play since that provides more action and competition for chips, but 2 players is ok.

Dixit 4 Jinx (80 Cards) You can play it with Dixit 6  & Dixit 7
Dixit 5  Journey (84 Cards)  You can play it with Dixit 1+2+3 Odyssey
Dixit 6 (43 Cards) You can play it with Dixit 4  & Dixit 7
Dixit 7 (43 Cards) You can play it with Dixit 4  & Dixit 6

In Camel Up, up to eight players bet on five racing camels, trying to suss out which will place first and second in a quick race around a pyramid. The earlier you place your bet, the more you can win — should you guess correctly, of course. Camels don't run neatly, however, sometimes landing on top of another one and being carried toward the finish line. Who's going to run when? That all depends on how the dice come out of the pyramid dice shaker, which releases one die at a time when players pause from their bets long enough to see who's actually moving!
Wanted
Ages 4+

This game is PERFECT for demo lessons or summer classes with 2- 12 students. Because you never know the level of the students or sometimes even the ages! This game works well with mixed ages. It’s easy to learn, and actually no language is needed. HOWEVER, since we’re teachers, let me tell you how to add learning to this fast-action game! FIRST, whenever the students make the actions, have them shout out sentences or words. Then, when they get faster at that, have them expand the sentence. OR whoever is the fastest can ask the person who was the slowest a question OR give them a dare. Join the shopping group for more ideas of this great game！

name: Fidget Cube
description:
Good for that noisy student in class, or for those boring meetings in Chinese that you are forced to attend. 

Read below for more details.

items.value:
Fidget Cube/Spinners
 
We’ve all had that one student who couldn’t sit still in class, constantly tapping a pencil or bothering others. This was created for those students. HOWEVER, some students will feel jealous if the “naughty” student gets to play with a toy. How do you solve this? My solution was to tell the students, this is not a toy, it is for helping some people study, you can use it ONLY if you sit nicely, don’t interrupt other students, and hold it in your pocket/under the table/out of sight, if you drop it or make noise with it, I will take it back. I let each student in the class use it when we first introduce it, once the newness wears off, they will forget about it. Then I will continue to let the fidgety student continue to use it (as long as they follow the rules)

Liar!
Best for ages: 6+
 
Super funny game, great for laughs. You don’t have to use the cards that come with the game, if you want to change the target language. There are two different ways to play the game with the cards, but the glasses/noses can be used for many other ways.
 
For large groups, asking review questions the team leader could wear the nose.
The teacher could wear it and if students answer the question, the teacher adds another nose.
It’s silly, it’s fun, it’s a great addition to any classroom. I’ve tried this with adults, but never with a one to one business class!
 
If you don’t want your students to lie to each other, you call also call this game “Just joking!” and explain it’s ok to “bluff” if you’re playing a game.

name: 5 Second Rule

items.value: Here's a great game that can be adapted for more advanced students in an ESL classroom, or even enjoyed with your coworkers at a company party.
If you want to make the game easier... give the students a longer time to answer.
If you have a large class... have them answer in groups of 3.
If you want to practice writing... you can ask students to write answers. Give points for unique answers!
Don't forget to pre-teach difficult or unfamiliar vocabulary... Pick 10 cards, go throw them together with the students. Then choose them at random and give them 5 seconds to answer.
You can also adapt the questions to fit your level of students or content from your textbooks if your school insists.

Another variation: Have students write the topic on the top of their paper, then write three answers. Put the answers in a bag/box, take one out at random and let students guess whose answers they are!
Cool bonus!
The timer that you get with this game can be used for other games/activities. If you need a longer timer, check here for this awesome classroom set.

For ages 7+
Up to 6 players

Why use this for English class? Well, during the game you can practice numbers, counting, numerical order, addition, or higher level concepts of strategy and bidding. OR you can learn the names of the different types of houses. It’s a great game at the end of class as a filler, or learn how to use games as a “prize” in our VIP group.

OR you could just use the pictures to make a writing/speaking prompt. You can let students pick which house is their favorite and tell you why. For adults you can have them try to guess the real prices of the house and research on the internet. You can discuss the culture/history/architecture of the houses. Tell a story about the people you think might live in this house.

name: Pictureka!
description: Exciting games of visual hide and seek; 100 different mission cards in 3 categories; Includes 9 two-sided gameboard tiles, 108 cards, dice, timer and instructions;For 2 or more people

items.value:
Pictureka! is a new kind of game, both in mechanic as in artwork. The mechanic is invigorating with its large square gaming tiles. The game board is composed of 3 by 3 game tiles, so the game board on which is played is a huge square of 63 cm x 63 cm. This is large enough for several players to be able to play the game at the same time. The game board is “alive”, it is not a static board as the tiles are flipped over, turned and moved. So it is not possible to memory map the board. The mechanic of an ever changing board makes it not only fun; also the challenge is kept into the game all the time.

 

A game turn 
Players will have to throw a color dice at the beginning of their turn. According to the color thrown (3 possibilities) they must draw a mission card of the same color. There are 3 kinds of missions.

 

How to win the game? 
Be the first one to have successfully accomplished 10 missions. Each successful mission gives 1 point, so be the first one to get 10 points.

Qwirkle
 
My students like to call this one “English Mahjong” even though there are no English words in it! The pieces of the game are small wooden blocks with beautiful shapes on them. They like to “shuffle” the pieces like Mahjong, and that’s something they usually see grandparents doing, it’s silly but exciting for them. Now, how to make this game full of English? Well of course, first you give names to the different shapes. Now you add a bit of basic game language (found in our Basic Game PDF) Then finish up with counting up your points in English. Great game for a “prize” or as a time filler.

name: Baby's Very First Touchy-Feely Christmas Play Book

items.value: This revised edition of Tolkien’s famous illustrated letters from Father Christmas to his children includes a number of pictures and letters that have not been seen in print before. The perfect Christmas gift for Tolkien lovers of all ages.

This classic festive book of Tolkien’s amazing Father Christmas letters written to his children between the 1920s and the 1940s has been reworked into a new and attractive edition. It contains brand new high-quality digital reproductions of his amazing letters and pictures, including a number them that have never been printed before.

‘My dear children, I am more shaky than usual this year. The North Polar Bear’s fault. It was the biggest bang in the world, and the most monstrous firework there has ever been. It turned the North Pole black!’

Every December an envelope bearing a stamp from the North Pole would arrive for J. R. R. Tolkien’s children. Inside would be a letter in strange spidery handwriting and a beautiful coloured drawing or some sketches. The letters were from Father Christmas.
They told wonderful tales of life at the North Pole:
• How all the reindeer got loose and scattered presents all over the place.
• How the accident-prone Polar Bear climbed the North Pole and fell through the roof of Father Christmas’s house into the dining-room
• How he broke the Moon into four pieces and made the Man in it fall into the back garden
• How there were wars with the troublesome horde of goblins who lived in the caves beneath the house!

Sometimes the Polar Bear would scrawl a note, and sometimes Ilbereth the Elf would write in his elegant flowing script, adding yet more life and humour to the stories. From the first note to Tolkien’s eldest son in 1920 to the final poignant letter to his daughter in 1943, this book collects all the remarkable letters and pictures in one enchanting edition. No reader, young or old, can fail to be charmed by the inventiveness of Tolkien’s Letters from Father Christmas.
